## What are GBIF and OBIS?

::: {.columns .v-center-container}
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify icon-park international size=3x >}}

<br>

{{< iconify gala data size=3x >}}

<br>

{{< iconify pepicons-print people-circle size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
GBIF and OBIS are international initiatives that aim to provide open access to biodiversity occurrence data.

<br>

Although they are most well-known for their publishing platforms, and their role as data aggregators...

<br>

...both initiatives represent an investment from the international political community and a vibrant scientific community of nodes, publishers, and users of standards and practices.
:::
:::

## What are GBIF and OBIS?

```{r}

# Generate data holdings stats

library(dplyr)
library(httr2)

options(scipen=999)

# GBIF Stats
gbif_occ_ct <- rgbif::occ_count() %>% 
  scales::comma()

gbif_dataset_ct <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.gbif.org/v1/dataset/search?limit=0") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json() %>% 
  .[["count"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

gbif_publisher_ct <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.gbif.org/v1/organization?limit=0&isEndorsed=true") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json() %>% 
  .[["count"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

gbif_paper_ct <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.gbif.org/v1/literature/search?contentType=literature&literatureType=journal&relevance=GBIF_USED&peerReview=true&limit=0") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json() %>% 
  .[["count"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

# OBIS Stats
stats <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.obis.org/statistics") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json()

obis_occ_ct <-  stats %>% 
  .[["records"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

obis_dataset_ct <- stats %>% 
  .[["datasets"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

obis_taxa_ct <- stats %>% 
  .[["species"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

```

## What are GBIF and OBIS?

::: {style="font-size: 50%; text-align: center"}
Map of the GBIF and OBIS networks. Countries where there is at least one GBIF node are in blue. Yellow points represent OBIS nodes.
:::

```{r}
#| fig-align: center
#| out-width: "100%"
#| fig-alt: Map of the GBIF and OBIS networks.  Countries where there is at least one GBIF node are in blue.  Yellow points represent OBIS nodes.

# Generate Map of GBIF and OBIS nodes

library(dplyr)
library(rgbif)
library(robis)
library(ggplot2)

gbif_nodes <- rgbif::nodes(limit = 1000) %>% 
  .[["data"]] %>% 
  select(title, country)

obis_nodes <- robis::node() %>% 
  select(name, lon,lat) %>% 
  sf::st_as_sf(coords = c("lon", "lat"), crs = 4326)
  
countries <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(returnclass = "sf")


ggplot(data = countries) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = postal %in% gbif_nodes$country)) +
  geom_sf(
    data = obis_nodes,
    inherit.aes = FALSE,
    color = "black",
    fill = "#F0E442",
    shape = 21,
    size = 4
  ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "None") +
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-180, 180),
           ylim = c(-90, 90)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("grey", "#56B4E9"))

```

## What are GBIF-US and OBIS-USA?

![](images/USGS_ID_green.png){height="75"} ![](images/IOOS_Emblem_Primary_B_RGB.jpg){height="75"} ![](images/NSF_Official_logo_High_Res_1200ppi.png){height="100"}

::: {style="font-size: 75%; text-align: left"}
USGS-SAS Biogeographic Science Branch manages the US nodes: GBIF-US and OBIS-USA.

-   represent US interests in the international initiatives
-   advise the US scientific community on biodiversity informatics, data, and standards
-   mobilize and synthesize data to enhance its FAIRness and relevance on national and international scales.

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
We also manage the [OBIS-USA](https://ipt-obis.gbif.us/) and [GBIF-US](https://ipt.gbif.us/) Integrated Publishing Toolkits (IPTs)!
:::
:::

## Why do we work with GBIF and OBIS?

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: {.columns .v-center-container}
::: {.column width="50%"}
![*Sparkly fountains need robust plumbing systems.* <br>- Terry McConnell (International Digital Twins of the Ocean Summit 2022)](images/67725_image_access_800/1_06_10_022012_image_access_800.jpg){fig-alt="https://ark.digitalcommonwealth.org/ark:/50959/r781wg156" height="300"}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
The US has been a voting participant in GBIF since 2001 and became an OBIS-USA node in 2005.

<br>

The USGS is shepherding over two decades of investment in the robust plumbing needed for national and global biodiversity science and data.
:::
:::
:::

## How are GBIF and OBIS the same?

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji whale size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
Both are active and energetic communities that develop, maintain, and promote standards and practices for biodiversity science and have been doing so for \> 20 years
:::
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji unlocked size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
Both promote open data and science, and publish massive amounts of standardized biological observations through their platforms
:::
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji handshake-medium-dark-skin-tone-medium-skin-tone size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
Have signed a [letter of agreement](https://www.gbif.org/news/6M8YYYirX3bK57bHaIpd0U/ocean-biodiversity-information-system-and-gbif-update-and-expand-cooperation-agreement) in recognition that their respective communities will benefit from more streamlined ways of working together. A stronger action plan is forthcoming.
:::
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji clipboard size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
GBIF and OBIS are built on the same data and metadata standards, and share open-source tools
:::
:::
:::

## Important Differences

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji jellyfish size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
GBIF has a global scope. OBIS includes marine occurrences only.
:::
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji money-bag size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
GBIF is funded by individual participant countries. We fund GBIF-US through the NSF. OBIS is funded by UNESCO, an agency of the United Nations.
:::
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
::: columns
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify openmoji yin-yang size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
GBIF-US and OBIS-USA are unusual in that both nodes are managed by the same people.
:::
:::
:::

## How does it work?

![](images/gbif_workflow.png)

::: {style="font-size: 75%; text-align: left"}
This is an illustration of the GBIF workflow. The OBIS workflow is similar.
:::

## What do GBIF and OBIS do well?

-   Coordinate and serve interoperable observations of biological occurrence
-   Promote and catalyze progress for open science and FAIR data
-   Searching data at the occurrence level
-   Track data use and [citations](https://www.gbif.org/literature-tracking)
-   Well designed tools and guidance exist for self-publishing
-   Active and diverse community

## So, why use GBIF and OBIS?

Off-the-shelf platforms for publishing and tracking use of biological occurrence data with minimal financial or staffing investment. USGS, and SpringerNature, accept GBIF as an archival repository, publishing to OBIS-USA satisfies NOAA archiving requirements.

![](images/mountain_of_FAIR.png)

## Sustainablity - International

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Both organizations rely on regular international investment for funding.
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
OBIS recently transitioned from a project to a program, which means it now receives core UNESCO/IOC funding and staff support to enable the activity to operate on a permanent basis.
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Open standards and science means that migration of data would be relatively simple in the event of a surprise shutdown.
:::

## Sustainablity - US

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
GBIF-US is funded by NSF (\~ \$600k / year). There is a [US Delegation](https://www.gbif.us/community/) that guides GBIF for US interests.

OBIS-USA is funded through US participation in UN and UNESCO.

For operation of both nodes, USGS funds the node staff salary + travel. NOAA IOOS also contributes staff.
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Both IPTs could easily transition to other management and continue to operate without US funding
:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Both secretariats have funding and training in place for new nodes and node managers
:::

-   Expansion of US node staff

## Two Standards

1.  [Darwin Core (DwC)](https://dwc.tdwg.org/terms/): Describe your biological observation.
2.  [Ecological Metadata Language (EML)](https://eml.ecoinformatics.org/): Describe your dataset.

## The Darwin Core Archive (DwC-A)

![](https://manual.obis.org/images/dwca.png)

## The DNADerivedData extension

::: {style="font-size: 75%; text-align: left"}
The [DNADerivedData extension](https://rs.gbif.org/extension/gbif/1.0/dna_derived_data_2022-02-23.xml) extends occurrence data with molecular biology metadata.

It mostly consists of terms from:

-   GGBN Data Standard
-   GSC MIxS (Minimum Information about any (X) Sequence)
-   MIQE (The Minimum Information for Publication of Quantitative Real-Time PCR Experiments). <br>

::: {layout-ncol="2"}
Guidance is available: [Publishing DNA-derived data through biodiversity data platforms](https://docs.gbif.org/publishing-dna-derived-data/en/). The guide handles barcoding, metabarcoding, metagenomics and qPCR/ddPCR.

![](images/dna_guide.png){fig-align="center" width="500"}
:::
:::

## Examples of DwC Terms

::: {style="font-size: 50%; text-align: left"}
```{r}
#| label: tbl-basics
#| tbl-cap: Example Occurrence Data From [Silliman et al., 2023](https://obis.org/dataset/210efc7c-4762-47ee-b4b5-22a0f436ef44)

#Make table of Gomecc data

#make rds from download
#df <- robis::occurrence(datasetid = "210efc7c-4762-47ee-b4b5-22a0f436ef44", extensions = "DNADerivedData")
#saveRDS(df, file = "obis_210efc7c-4762-47ee-b4b5-22a0f436ef44.rds")

df <- readRDS("obis_210efc7c-4762-47ee-b4b5-22a0f436ef44.rds")

occ <- df %>% 
  group_by(scientificNameID) %>% 
  slice(2) %>% 
  filter(scientificNameID %in% c("urn:lsid:marinespecies.org:taxname:233015")) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  select(occurrenceID,
         eventDate,
         locality,
         locationID,
         decimalLatitude,
         decimalLongitude,
         geodeticDatum,
         minimumDepthInMeters,
         maximumDepthInMeters) %>% 
  tidyr::gather(key = "Term", value = "Example", everything())

occ %>% knitr::kable()

```
:::

  robis::dna_records() %>% 
  mutate(occurrenceID = occID) %>% 
  select(occurrenceID,
         DNA_sequence,
         concentration,
         target_gene,
         target_subfragment,
         pcr_primer_forward,
         pcr_primer_reverse,
         pcr_primer_name_forward,
         pcr_primer_name_reverse,
         pcr_primer_reference,
         seq_meth,
         otu_class_appr,
         otu_db,
         otu_seq_comp_appr
         ) %>% 
  tidyr::gather(key = "Term", value = "Example", everything())

occ %>% knitr::kable()
